name: mecoprop production | mecoprop | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/8440/documentation

This dataset represents the production of mecoprop (1 kg of active ingredient). Raw materials are modelled with a stoichiometric calculation.  Energy consumption is modelled with data from a similar process. The emissions are estimated. Infrastructure is included with a default value.;[This dataset was already contained in the ecoinvent database version 2. It was not individually updated during the transfer to ecoinvent version 3. Life Cycle Impact Assessment results may still have changed, as they are affected by changes in the supply chain, i.e. in other datasets. This dataset was generated following the ecoinvent quality guidelines for version 2. It may have been subject to central changes described in the ecoinvent version 3 change report (http://www.ecoinvent.org/database/ecoinvent-version-3/reports-of-changes/), and the results of the central updates were reviewed extensively. The changes added e.g. consistent water flows and other information throughout the database. The documentation of this dataset can be found in the ecoinvent reports of version 2, which are still available via the ecoinvent website. The change report linked above covers all central changes that were made during the conversion process.]

From reception of precursors (chlorine, ethylene, methanol, carbon monoxide, water decarbonised, and phenol) at the factory gate.

This activity ends with  mecoprop  at the factory gate. The dataset includes the input materials, energy uses, infrastructure and emissions. The dataset doesn't include emulsives, additives etc.
category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/202:Manufacture of other chemical products/2021:Manufacture of pesticides and other agrochemical products

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The inventory is modelled for Europe.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Mecoprop is a pesticide produced in three steps from phenol: ;C6H6O + CH4O → C7H8O + H2O;C7H8O + Cl2 → C7H7ClO + HCl;C7H7ClO + C3H5ClO2 → C10H14ClO3 + HCl;A precursor that is used for the mecoprop production is 2-chloro-propionic acid (C3H5ClO2).;2-Chloro-propionic acid (C3H5ClO2) is produced from propionic acid and chlorine: ;C3H6O2 + Cl2 → C3H5ClO2 + HCl

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=RER
Mecoprop is an odorless, white to light brown crystalline solid. It is moderately soluble in water and readily soluble in acetone, diethyl ether, ethanol, ethyl acetate, and chloroform. It exists as a mixture of two optically active isomers of which one, the R+ form, mecoprop-p is herbicidally active. It is stable to heat, hydrolysis, reduction, and oxidation. It is acidic. Solutions of the salts of mecoprop are stable for several years under normal storage conditions. In cooler temperatures, the salt may crystallize out of solution but will re-dissolve on warming.
The name "MCPP" is approved by the Japanese Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries.
The (R)-isomer of this substance has the ISO common name mecoprop-P.
Mecoprop is a selective, systemic, hormonelike herbicide used post-emergence for the control of broad-leaved weeds in wheat, barley, oats, seed crops, grassland, etc.

flow.name: mecoprop
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/202:Manufacture of other chemical products/2021:Manufacture of pesticides and other agrochemical products

exchanges.description:
EcoSpold01Location=UCTE
Estimation, assuming a default value, originated from calculation of avarage consumption of electricity and heat per kg of product (3.2 MJ kg-1), and a resulting amount of electricity of 0,333 kW for every reaction step per kg reaction product, considering that the demand is made up of a mix that inlcudes 38% electricity.  Additionally, reaction steps are approximated with energy consumption data, assuming that inventory flows can be estimated using process data for basic operation steps, available for specific organic chemicals.

Further references:

Kim S., Overcash M.: Energy in chemical manufacturing processes: gate-to-gate information for life cycle assessment. In: Journal of Chemical Technology & Biotechnology vol. 78,  no. 9: 995-1005(11). 2003

exchanges.description:
Estimation, assuming a default value, originated from calculation of avarage consumption of electricity and heat per kg of product (3.2 MJ kg-1), and a resulting amount of heat of 2 MJ for every reaction step per kg reaction product, considering that the demand is made up of a mix that inlcudes 12% steam from external energy sources.  Additionally, reaction steps are approximated with energy consumption data, assuming that inventory flows can be estimated using process data for basic operation steps, available for specific organic chemicals.

Further references:

Kim S., Overcash M.: Energy in chemical manufacturing processes: gate-to-gate information for life cycle assessment. In: Journal of Chemical Technology & Biotechnology vol. 78,  no. 9: 995-1005(11). 2003

flow.name: Water
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/unspecified

exchanges.description: Estimation, based on the assumption that 0.2% of volatile input materials is emitted to air occurring from the purge vent, the destillation vent and fugitive emission sources. Remaining gases like CH4 or CO are oxidated to CO2. The carbon contained in the removed carbon compounds from wastewater treatment was accounted as CO2 emissions to air (assuming  a removal efficiency of 90%).

flow.name: Phenol
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description:
Estimation, based on a production capacity of 50,000 t per year and a plant life time of 50 years, therefore an amount of 4X10-10 units per kg of produced chemical  is aded to the unit process of the respective chemical. The amount is accounted for each production step. This might be an overestimation in some multistep syntheses.
EcoSpold01Location=RER
